title: Cossington, Kent
text:
Cossington is a small farm settlement on <a href="Blue%20Bell%20Hill">Blue Bell Hill</a> north of <a href="Maidstone">Maidstone</a> in the <a href="England">English</a> county of <a href="Kent">Kent</a>.
It is the site of a <a href="spring%20%28hydrosphere%29">spring</a> and also the site of a now lost group of <a href="sarsen">sarsen</a> stones thought to possibly be the remains of a <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> <a href="chambered%20long%20barrow">chambered long barrow</a> and one of the <a href="Medway%20megaliths">Medway megaliths</a>. The area is very close to the nearby sites of <a href="Kit%27s%20Coty%20House">Kit's Coty House</a> and the <a href="Countless%20Stones">Countless Stones</a>.
Little is known of the stones at Cossington; the lack of available knowledge and <a href="antiquarian">antiquarian</a> interest at the site may mean that they may not be megalithic remains but natural <a href="periglacial">periglacial</a> stones. The upstanding stones may have been destroyed in the nineteenth century to provide building stone for the military garrisons at <a href="Sheerness">Sheerness</a> and <a href="Chatham%2C%20Kent">Chatham</a> further downstream in the <a href="Medway">Medway</a> valley.
In 1980 four stones buried in a pit were found in the area by a local farmer who broke his plough on them. The precise location has not been shared by the archaeologist who excavated them, apparently for fear of treasure hunters.
